en: ABSTRACT COMPARISON OF RELATIVE PMT CAINS MEASURED AT THE UNIVERSITY OF IOWA AND THOSE OBTAINED FROM SOURCE RUN DATA TAKEN DURING THE HF TEST BEAM 2004 PERIOD The Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) is built for studying particles from proton- proton collisions. The I IF Forward Calorimeter in CMS detects forward jets and thus provides additional help for identifying particles. The HF Pholomultiplier lubes (PMTs) are used for converting Chercnkov light that comes from secondary particles in quartz fibers inside the HF Calorimeter absorber to electrical pulses. Therefore, the performance of PMTs is important in operation of the I IF Calorimeter. PMTs are tested at the University of Iowa PMT Test Station and their relative gains are measured. Then these PMTs are installed in the HF and some of the wedges were tested during the HF Test Beam 2004 period. In this thesis, the source run data taken during the HF Test Beam 2004 period are analyzed using "root", an Object Oriented Data Analysis Framework, and the obtained relative gains are compared with the relative gains measured at Iowa. The result of analysis show that, the relative gains measured at Iowa is highly correlated to those obtained from source run data taken at CHRN.

en: IV ABSTRACT CHANDRA OBSERVATIONS OF EX HYDRAE Ex Hydrae, an intermediate polar type cataclysmic variable X-ray binary system, is observed with Chandra, in the range of 0.3-10 keV with a total time of 59 ksec. The Chandra X-ray data of EX Hya was analyzed and then compared with the theoretical models. The best fit physical models are found to be the broken power law, thermal bremsstrahlung, comptonization and the disk models with an added iron emission line. The best fit parameters are Ti = 0.66, T2 = 10, for the energy indices, ^break - 6.76Ã¼Tey,and a hydrogen column density of Nh = 3.7lxlQ22 atoms /cm2, for broken power law with Fe-line at 9.43 keV with FWHM of 4.5 keV; a temperature of kT = 13.58 keV, with the Fe line at 9.63 keV with FWHM of 4.3 keV, and hydrogen column density of N# value islxlO17 atoms /cm2 for thermal bremsstrahlung; and temperature kT = 1.95 keV, optical depth of r = 32.36 for the comptonization after Lamb and Sanford model with the Fe line at 9.99 keV with FWHM value of 5.73 keV, and hydrogen column density of 2.54xl022 atoms /cm2. The best fit parameters for comptonization spectrum after Sunyaev and Titarchuk are, a temperature of kT = 1.64 keV, an optical depth of r = 33.87, with the Fe line at 9.86 keV with FWHM value of 5.41 keV, and a hydrogen column density of 1.17xl022 atoms /cm2. The best fit parameters for the blackbody disk model are Tin = 28.76keV, Fe line at 9.76keV with FWHM value of 5.21keV and hydrogen column density of 2.53xl022afoms/cm2, and the best fit parameters for the modified blackbody disk model are hydrogen column density of lxlO17 atoms /cm2, an accretion value of 1.85 Eddington Luminosities, with Fe Ã¼ne at 9.32 keV with FWHM value of 3.65 keV. Our results show that disc-fed model, and accretion curtain model could explain the continuum spectra of EX Hya.

en: IV ABSTRACT REPRESENTATIONS OF SOME GENERALIZED OSCILLATOR ALGEBRAS The representation of the oscillator algebra and of various generalized oscillator algebras have been investigated. The spectrum of the number operator or of the gener alized number operator has been obtained. In some cases, the existence of. the ground state was accepted. On the other hand, in some cases, the existence of the ground state was proved. In terms of the values of the parameters of the algebras, characteristics of the representations have been discussed.

FarklÄ± bÃ¼yÃ¼klÃ¼k ve yÃ¶nlerde amorf, gÃ¶zenekli ve siyah silisyumlarÄ±n optik mikroskop (OM), Atom Kuvvet Mikoroskop (AFM) ve TaramalÄ± Elektron Mikroskop (SEM) gÃ¶rÃ¼ntÃ¼leri elde edilmiÅŸtir.
en: ABSTRACT TEMPERATURE AND LASER POWER DEPENDENCE OF PHOTOLUMINESCENCE IN NANOCRYSTALLINE SILICON Crystalline silicon being dominant throughout the microelectronics industry has an indirect bandgap, and therefore is incapable of light emission. However, strong room temperature visible and near-IR luminescence from nanocrystalline silicon, e.g., amorphous silicon, porous silicon, and black silicon, has been observed. These silicon based materials are morphologically similar to each other, and have similar luminescence properties. We have studied the temperature and laser power dependence of the photoluminescence from these nanocrystalline silicons to fully characterize and optimize these materials in the pursuit of obtaining novel optoelectronic devices. Optical characterization method is used to analyze the microstructure, composition, band characteristics, and origin of luminescence from the nanocrystalline silicon. The photoluminescence (PL) spectra of amorphous, porous and black silicon as nanostructured silicon crystals were investigated in the 10 K-300 K temperature region in the 550-950 nm wavelength range. The behaviour of the emission band peak energy, and the intensity dependence of the emission band for different temperatures were studied. Structural characterization method is also used to obtain general surface characteristics and nanostructure patterns in order to assist in the understanding of the underlying PL mechanism of these nanostructured silicons. Optical microscope images, Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) and Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) images of amorphous, porous and black silicon as means of structural characterization were obtained at different magnifications and orientations.

en: IV ABSTRACT MONTE CARLO SIMULATION AND STATISTICAL ANALYSIS OF GENETIC INFORMATION CODING The rules that specify how the information contained in DNA codes amino acids, is called "the genetic code". We are investigating the importance of the genetic code on population dynamics. To do this, we propose a simple computational model which analyzes the effect of mutations on population. We find that the genetic code is not formed randomly. Moreover, we find that the number of amino acids in Nature is where the stability of population under mutations is optimum.

en: IV ABSTRACT MULTIPARAMETER GENERALIZATION OF DEFORMED PARTICLE ALGEBRAS In this study, we generalize deformed boson and fermion algebras by considering as many deformation parameters as possible. The restriction on the number of defor mation parameters emerges from the relations leaving the algebra consistent. In the bosonic part, we consider the Newton oscillator which is a one parameter generalization of the harmonic oscillator as a starting point. Then, we achieve the multiparameter generalization with d(d+ 1) parameters for d dimensional oscillator system. We also present the Fock representation of this oscillator. In the fermionic part, we first study the quantum group covariant two-parameter deformed fermion algebra. Then we show that if the quantum group symmetry is not preserved, then the number of deformation parameters in d dimension can be increased to 2(<2 - 1). We study the limiting case where all deformation parameters go to zero such that the deformed fermionic oscillator reduces to the orthofermion algebra. Finally, we investigate the symmetry properties of this limiting case.

en: Ill ABSTRACT A COMPARISON OF OPERATOR FORMALISMS OF LINEAR AND LOGARITHMIC TRAJECTORY DUAL MODELS In this thesis, the constructions of bosonic dual scattering amplitudes with linear trajectories and logarithmic trajectories are examined and operator formulations of dual models and their consequences are investigated. A comparison between the operator formalisms of linear and logarithmic trajectories is given. A new operator representation for the crossing symmetric JV-point function is established out of ^-deformed Newton oscillator creation and annihilation operators. The matrix element of the constructed operator JV-point function between the vacuum states provides us with a crossing symmetric scattering amplitude possessing the required factorization properties.

en: The Standard Model of particle physics has solved the problem of giving massesto quarks and leptons by introducing the Higgs particle which soon will be searched atthe Large Hadron Collider at CERN. Another problem of the Standard Model is thestrong CP violation problem which arises due to the interplay between the strong andweak sectors of the model. An understanding of this problem requires understandingthe instantons and the quark mixing. In this thesis I present my understanding of thesetopics and consider how the strong CP violation problem can be solved by introducingthe axion particle.

en: IV ABSTRACT THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN GENERAL ABILITY, SCIENTIFIC REASONING ABILITY, SCIENCE ACHIEVEMENT AND SCIENTIFIC ATTITUDE The purpose of this study was to investigate the interrelationships between general ability, scientific reasoning ability, science achievement and scientific attitude for grades 6, 7 and 8. However, it was also aimed to find the change in general ability, scientific reasoning ability and scientific attitude through secondary school years, and the difference in scientific reasoning ability, science achievement and scientific attitude for high, average and low ability groups. A general ability test was applied to separate students into ability groups. Classroom Test of Scientific Reasoning by Lawson (2000) was used to determine interview questions. These questions were used to measure more suitable reasoning patterns included in scientific reasoning for the level of students. Students' science lesson grades were taken as a measure of science achievement. Scientific Attitude Inventory II by Moore and Foy (1997) was applied to measure scientific attitude. Using a correlational design and Pearson r correlation coefficient, it was found that all the variables mentioned had positive relationships. Using One-way Analysis of Variance, it was seen that students (N = 247) at different grade levels did not have different scientific attitude and general ability scores. Scientific reasoning ability scores of 7th grade students with low and high ability were significantly higher than 6th grade students with low and high ability. Using independent samples t-test, girls (n = 130) were found to have significantly higher science achievement grades than boys (n = 117). Using One-way Analysis of Variance, high ability students were found to have significantly higher science achievement grades and scientific attitude than average and low ability students. Using an independent samples t-test, it was also found that high ability group had significantly higher interview scores which measured correlational flunking and hypothetico-deductive reasoning (two patterns of scientific reasoning).

en: IV ABSTRACT INHOMOGENEOUS QUANTUM INVARIANCE GROUP OF COMMUTING FERMIONS Since the middle of the twentieth century, physicists have concentrated on find ing quantum counterparts of classical systems. When a classical system is quantized its invariance group may still be a classical group. In the nineteen-eighties it was shown that when some classical systems are quantized, their classical group becomes a quan tum group so that the system is invariant under a quantum group. So quantum groups play an important role in carrying physical properties to the quantum world. In this thesis we will first review the fermionic and the bosonic algebras and their inhomogeneous invariance quantum groups. Then we will introduce the commuting fermion algebra and construct its inhomogeneous invariance quantum group.

en: IV ABSTRACT NONCOMMUTATIVE PHASE AND THE UNITARIZATION OF THE QUANTUM GROUP GLm{2) In this thesis, a new Â«-operation (or unitarized form) is defined for the two- parameter quantum group GLp,q(2) in the case that pq is real, and the new group is denoted by UPiq{2). The most interesting aspect of our construction is the appearance of the noncommutative phase described by the unitary operator u. The operator u with a central hermitian operator s allow us to extend the algebra of the quantum group GLp>q(2) in order to obtain not only the Â«-operation but also the Â«-relations throughout the new algebra of Up,q(2). It is shown how certain Â«-representations of the quantum group SUq(2) can be extended in order to give Â«-representations of Up>q(2). This not only allows us to verify the algebraic relations in a representation, it also gives a hint of possible physical interpretations of the algebraic generators as operators.

en: One dimensional potential wells are described as a collection of consecutive thin slices, each approximated by a Dirac delta well. Bound state energies of these Dirac delta well conglomerates are calculated, using a method based on Transfer and S-Matrix formalisms. It is observed that the method, a variant of the Born approximation, works best for the ground state energies of narrow and shallow wells. The approximate results compare favorably with the known exact results of several potential well problems.

en: IV ABSTRACT FOLDING MODEL CALCULATION OF NUCLEAR. POTENTIAL ENERGY The electrostatic potential energy content of any spherically symmetric electric charge distribution can be calculated with more ease by means of Gauss' law, which is valid only for 1/r potentials. For atomic nuclei, even for the simplest "realistic" form of N-N interaction, this is not quite possible through Gauss' law. It would, therefore, be necessary to work out the complete interaction integrals. Such integrals are in the form of folding/convolution integrals which are usually met in Fourier or other similar integral transformations. It turns out that for a class of functions, applicable to represent nuclear distributions and forces in coarse but at least visually satisfactory way, such "convolution theorems" help to evaluate interaction integrals in analytical form. We, in this work, wanted to benefit from this in evaluating nuclear potential energy by using nuclear distribution functions and N-N interaction forms suggested by other authors for various purposes. Our results, although neither short nor extremely simple, are expressible in terms of elementary functions. Since, however, it is not possible to find direct experimental values to compare, we, instead, supplemented our potential energy with a kinetic energy function obtained in so-called Local Density Approximation. It is shown that with some reasonable adjustments -constrained by model-independent Coulomb energy- we could reproduce results for total binding energies given by semi-empirical mass formulae.

en: IV ABSTRACT D.C. PHOTOCONDUCTIVITY IN As2Se3 THIN FILMS In this thesis, the D.C. photoconductivity in amorphous thin films of As2Se$ is investigated. The temperature dependence of dark, and photo currents are explored at the interval 240 - 360 K. Three regimes are observed in the photoconductivity at the given range of temperature. The results are criticized according to the theory and other data and found to be in accordance with them.

en: IV ABSTRACT MIGRATION OF GIANT PLANETS BY DYNAMICAL FRICTION IN AN EVOLVING PLANETESIMAL DISK In this work, the model for the migration of planets introduced by Del Popolo is further improved. The assumption of Del Popolo that the surface density in plan- etesimals is proportional to that of gas is removed. Since the evolution of the radial distribution of solids is governed by many processes: gas-solid coupling, coagulation, sedimentation, evaporation and condensation, so that the distribution of planetesimals emerging from a turbulent disk does not necessarily exhibit that of gas. In order to obtain this evolution a method developed by Stepinski and Valageas which using a series of simplifying assumptions, is able to simultaneously follow the evolution of gas and solid particles for up to 107yr is used. Then, the disc model is coupled to the migration model introduced by Del Popolo in order to obtain the migration rate of the planet in the planetesimal disc and to study how the migration rate depends on the disc mass, on its evolution and on some values of the dimensionless viscosity parameter a. It is found that in the case of disks having a total mass of 10_3MQ < Md < 10-1MQ and 10-4 < a < 10-1 planets can migrate inward over a large distance, while if Ma < 1Q~3MQ the planets remain almost at their initial position for a > 10~3 and only in the case a < 10-3 the planets move to a minimum value of orbital radius of 2 AU. Besides the model gives a good description of the observed distribution of plan ets in the period range 0-20 days. Hence dynamical friction between planets and the planetesimal disk provides a good mechanism to explain the properties of discovered extra-solar giant planets

en: IV ABSTRACT MICROSPHERE BASED OPTICAL BIOSENSORS Optical microsphere resonators have recently utilized in quantum optics, laser science, spectroscopy, and optoelectronics and attracted increasing interest due to their unique optical properties. Microspheres possess high quality factor (Q-factor) optical morphology dependent resonances, and have relatively small volumes. Q-factor can be defined as how sharp morphology dependent resonance in the elastic scattering spectrum. High-Q morphology dependent resonances are very sensitive to the refractive index change and microsphere uniformity. These tiny optical cavities, whose diameters may vary from a few to several hundred micrometers, have resonances with reported Q- factors as large as 3x 109. Due to their sensitivity, morphology dependent resonances of microspheres are also considered for biosensing applications. For instance, binding of a protein or other biomolecules can be monitored by observing the wavelength shift of morphology dependent resonances. A biosensor, based on this optical phenomena, can even detect a single molecule if a good system design is achieved. In this work, elastic scattering spectra from the microspheres of different mate rials are experimentally obtained and morphology dependent resonances are observed. Furthermore, the morphology dependent resonances of microspheres for biosensor ap plications were studied theoretically. Keywords: Biosensor, Microsphere, Morphology Dependent Resonances.

en: IV ABSTRACT A STUDY OF THE LIGHT-INDUCED EFFECTS IN AMORPHOUS CHALCOGENIDE THIN FILMS In this thesis, light-induced changes in the photoconductivity of amorphous chalcogenide thin films are investigated. The room temperature photoconductivity degradation and low temperature photoconductivity enhancement effects are observed and studied. On the basis of experimental data concerning the changes in dark conductivity, room temperature photoconductivity, temperature dependence of dark conductivity and temperature dependence of photoconductivity of the films upon prolonged light-soaking, it is found that among the two basic models recently proposed to account for the mechanism of the light-induced metastable defect formation, the intercluster interaction model seems to be much more successful than the charged defect model in describing the observed phenomena. Changes in the density of state distributions of the films upon Hght-soaking are also investigated by means of the phase shift analysis of modulated photocurrent method.

en: IV ABSTRACT REPRESENTATIONS OF THE QUANTUM MATRIX GROUP SLq(2,R) The quantum matrix group SLq(2,Ii) and its representations are investigated in this thesis. A q-deformation of SL(2, R) is obtained by first transforming a matrix belonging to SL(2,R) by a similarity transformation and then deforming the matrix thus obtained in accordance with the commutation relations obtained from SLq(2, C). The representations of the Hopf algebra satisfied by the matrix elements are then constructed.

en: ABSTRACT STAR-DISK INTERACTION AND ANOMALOUS X-RAY PULSARS Neutron stars (NSs) are borne in supernova events. It is possible that some of the ejected matter remains gravitationally bound to the NS and forms a fallback disk. Initially the NS rotates fast and the interaction with the disk slows down the star via the propeller mechanism. During this stage the initial fast rotation of the star inhibits the inflowing matter to accrete onto the NS. When the NS and the disk are sufficiently close to the torque equilibrium, accretion starts and the gravitational energy of the accreting matter is released as X-rays. It is investigated whether this accretion stage can be associated with Anomalous X^ray Pulsars which are spinning down young neutron stars with periods P* = 6 - 12 s and X-ray luminosities Lx ~ 1035 - 1036 erg s~l. Our results indicate that this is possible only if the propeller torque is very efficient and a small fraction of the inflowing matter can accrete. NSs with less massive disks emerge as radio pulsars. In some conditions the inner radius of the fallback disk can track the speed of light cylinder radius, Rl = cP* /27r, indicating that fallback disks can torque radio pulsars. The initial mass of the fallback disk can be considered as a new parameter in the evolution of a pulsar.

en: IV CARDIAC MOTION ANALYSIS IN MRI FOR CLASSIFICATION ABSTRACT Although several techniques exist for the analysis of cardiac tagged MR images, a rapid screening tool do not yet exits. Our proposed technique tries to perform rapid classification to diagnose the abnormalities in human left ventricle and the final aim of this study is to identify the investigated myocardium in the analyzed tagged MR images as pathological and non. In this thesis, images are first analyzed using harmonic phase (HARP) analysis and synthetic tags are computed over the myocardium. The data is normalized to perform a comparison between different myocardiums having various tag lines and time frames. The aim of the normalization is to eliminate the shift, scale and rotation variance. Cubic curves are fitted to the normalized tags and curve parameters are compared at various regions of the myocardium. In this initial study, the curve parameters are examined with probability density function between normal and diseased hearts, such as left ventricles with dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) and infarcted regions. Finally, the confusion matrix is evaluated to examine the correctness of the segmentation algorithm. This method could be a very fast and automatic screening tool for identifying diseased locations in tagged MRI. Keywords: tagged MRI, HARP, cardiac motion analysis

en: IV ABSTRACT MONTE CARLO SIMULATION OF LATTICE GROWTH FROM SOLUTION WITH LATTICE DEFECTS IN THREE DIMENSIONS The structure of surface growth from solution and formation of defects during the growth of a crystal have been studied with the use of a kinetic Monte Carlo method. Simulations have been performed for a three-dimensional lattice. The model used in this thesis takes into account three events; adsorption, desorption and diffusion. The growth rate is controlled by chemical potential change of solid and fluid phases (A/i). The solid-on-solid criterion, which is commonly used in modeling crystal growth, is not assumed in the present study. This extends to make lattice defects (vacancies) created in the crystal. It is shown that for sufficiently large A/jl, the surface becomes rough and large voids are formed as well as point defects. It is also shown that the density of defects increases as A/i becomes large.

YÃ¶ntem, ortaya Ã§Ä±kan normal formun karmaÅŸÄ±klÄ±ÄŸÄ± nedeniyle lineerleÅŸtirilmiÅŸ kÄ±smÄ±n Ã¶zdeÄŸerlerinden birinin sÄ±fÄ±r olduÄŸu durumlarda doÄŸrudan uygulanamamaktadÄ±r. Li neerleÅŸtirilmiÅŸ kÄ±smÄ±n Ã¶zdeÄŸerlerini deÄŸiÅŸtiren rasyonel dÃ¶nÃ¼ÅŸÃ¼mler Sprott C and E sistemleri Ã¼zerinde uygulanarak daha basit sistemler elde edilebileceÄŸi gÃ¶sterilmiÅŸtir. Fonksiyonel Manyetik Rezonans GÃ¶rÃ¼ntÃ¼leme verilerinin incelenmesinde kullanÄ±labile cek bir fraktal analiz yÃ¶ntemi Ã¶nerilmiÅŸ, nÃ¼kleer spin sistemlerinde olasÄ± kaotik davranÄ±ÅŸ kaynaklarÄ± hakkÄ±nda Ã¶n sonuÃ§lar takdim edilmiÅŸtir.
en: ABSTRACT NORMAL FORMS, NONLOCAL CHAOTIC BEHAVIOR IN SPROTT AND NMR SYSTEMS Poincare's theory of normal forms is applied to a number of simple chaotic Sprott flows that have resonant eigenvalues. It is shown that the normal form expansion can give significant information not limited to the local properties of chaotic attractors, but also, on nonlocal properties such as positive and zero Liapunov exponents for systems that have the Hopf bifurcation property. Existence of a zero Liapunov exponent is indicated if the system has hyperbolic fixed points. The method is not directly applicable where an eigenvalue of the linearized part vanishes, because of the complexity of the normal form. Rational transformations that change the eigenvalue spectrum of the linearized parts are employed on the Sprott C and E systems to obtain simpler systems. A proposal on the possible use of fractal analysis methods on functional MRI data and preliminary results on possible sources of chaotic behavior inherent in nuclear spin systems are presented.

en: IV ABSTRACT ATLAS TRANSITION RADIATION TRACKER AND HIGGS PHYSICS RELATED TO EXTRA STANDARD MODEL FAMILIES The enhancement in the production cross-section of the Higgs boson via gluon fusion at hadron colliders due to the quarks of new SM families might be an indirect verification of the existence of extra SM families. With this motivation, we study the consequences of extra SM families on the observability of the Higgs boson. On the latter part of this thesis, we present the induced radioactivity studies of the ATLAS Inner Detector Transition Radiation Tracker (ID-TRT) and the TRT test run data analysis done to validate the performance of the detector under different conditions.

en: ABSTRACT NONSTANDARD COSMOLOGICAL METRICS Three cosmological metrics which are similar in their symmetry properties are discussed. The first one, a translationally invariant but rotationally non-symmetric metric gives a simple expanding universe solution, provided that momentum density in the x direction is chosen to be zero. As t goes to infinity, energy density remains constant and the universe approaches isotropy. A rotationally symmetric metric is con sidered secondly and this solution again gives expanding universe under the condition of zero momentum density in the radial direction. In contrast to the standard big bang model in which universe is a point at t = 0, in this model space is two dimensional at the beginning, then at latter times, it becomes three dimensional. The third metric is both rotationally and translationally symmetric. We first formulate it in Finsler space. We show that such a metric can be handled in six dimensional Riemanian space by introducing two additional internal dimensions and considering a special limit. Cosmo- logical solutions described by this metric give rise to an equation of state corresponding to a space dominated with domain walls and an internal space dominated with strings.

en: IV ABSTRACT THE SO(Nc) GAUGE THEORY IN THE LARGE Nc LIMIT In this thesis we study the large Nc limit of SO(Nc) gauge theory coupled to a real scalar field following ideas of Rajeev. We use light-cone coordinate system in order to deal with the complicated structure of the theory. We formulate a classical field theory using the color invariant bilinears of the field variables. These bilinears satisfy a simple quadratic constraint. One can compute the equations of motion in the linear approximation. These linearized equations give us the analog of the well-known 't Hooft equation of two dimensional QCD. Â¦ax rms^^Jwm^^

en: IV ABSTRACT CONDUCTIVITY MECHANISMS IN METALLIC GLASSES In this thesis, electrical conduction, in thin films of chalcogenide glasses, was studied. As2Se3, As2Te3 and AS2S3 samples have been subjected to electric fields of the order of 10 -10 V/cm and their d.c. conductivities were measured at temperatures between 200-410K, 200-360K and 200-360K respectively. Generally, the conductivity shows an exponential relation with the temperature of type a=Cexp(-E/kT). An application of the results to the above relation indicates a dominance of extended state conduction for As2Se3 and As2Te3 while hopping conduction is observed for AS2S3. A.c. conductivity of As2Se3, As2Te3 and AS2S3 samples were measured at temperatures 200-41 OK, 200-3 60K and 200-3 60K respectively in the frequency range between 5Hz and 5MHz. The results suggest that the conductivity consists of two components, one being independent of frequency and the other varying as of with frequency. The experimental results are in agreement with the Classical Barrier Hopping (CBH) conductivity model assuming different mechanisms for the d.c. and a.c. conductivities rather than the Extended Pair Approximation (EPA) model assuming the same mechanism for both d.c. and a.c. conductivities.

en: IV ABSTRACT SHAPE MEASUREMENTS BY USING ELECTRONIC SPECKLE PATTERN 1NTERFEROMETRY (ESPI) The surface profile of an Al thin film and its thickness have been observed by electronic speckle pattern interferometry (ESPI). The Michelson interferometer was used as our basic interferometric system to obtain interference fringes on a CCD camera. These interference fringes depend on the path differences due to the surface contours of the thin film. The experiments were performed with three different techniques, namely fast Fourier transform, phase shifting, and digital image subtraction; and these methods were compared with each other.

en: IV ABSTRACT TRANSPORT PROPERTIES IN AMORPHOUS CHALCOGENIDE GLASSES The density of localized states in the mobility gap of As2Se3 thin films has been determined over a range of 0.3eV from the Fermi level to the conduction band by the phase shift analysis of the modulated photocurrent (PSAMP) method. The dis tribution of density of states shows almost an exponential decay as the energy gets away from the conduction band. This indicates an overlap of conduction and valence band tails. Frequency-resolved photocurrent (FRPC) measurements were carried out on amorphous As2Se3 thin films between 298K and 353K. These measurements give lifetime distributions directly. It is found out that carrier lifetime depends on temper ature and excitation light intensity, thus it can be concluded that the recombination is through distant pairs and that there is an exponential distribution of traps within the mobility gap.

FarklÄ±laÅŸtÄ±rÄ±lmÄ±ÅŸ fizik derslerinin, bu Ã§alÄ±ÅŸmadaki grubun fen/fizik hakkÄ±ndaki gÃ¶rÃ¼ÅŸlerini/tutumlarÄ±nÄ± olumlu yÃ¶nde deÄŸiÅŸtirdiÄŸi, klasik derslerle karÅŸÄ±laÅŸtÄ±rÄ±ldÄ±ÄŸÄ±nda ise farklÄ±laÅŸtÄ±rÄ±lmÄ±ÅŸ dersler ile daha Ã§ok Ã¶ÄŸrenciye ulaÅŸÄ±labileceÄŸi, ve daha yÃ¼ksek basan dÃ¼zeyi gÃ¶zlemlenebileceÄŸi sonucuna varÄ±lmÄ±ÅŸtÄ±r
en: ABSTRACT THE EFFECT OF DIFFERENTIATED PHYSICS INSTRUCTION ON 9th GRADE GIFTED LEARNERS This study aimed to delineate the effect of differentiated 9th grade physics instruction on gifted learners in terms of attitude and achievement. The 1 1-week period of physics instruction was differentiated in one or more of the three components (content, process, and products) on the basis of students' readiness and/or learning styles. 28 ninth grade gifted students formed the sample. Attitude toward physics/science was probed by Views About Sciences Survey (VASS P20LB) as a pre-test. Appropriate teaching/learning environments and experiences were tailored in order to respond to the educational needs of all learners. At the end of the treatment, in order to probe the change in attitude VASS P20LB as a posttest, and in order to collect the evaluation of students about the period, Sethian Questionnaire was administered. Statistical tests and qualitative analysis of the questionnaire showed that differentiated instruction had a positive effect on learner's views about science/physics. Paired samples t-test showed that the standard deviation of the physics grades was significantly lower compared to that of mathematics grades in the previous year and in the same term, and to the standard deviation of science grades in the previous year. The mean of the physics grades was significantly higher than that of the previous year's and the same term's mathematics grades, and the mean of the previous year's science grades. It was concluded that differentiated instruction changed the view/attitude toward science/physics of the sample set positively. A lower physics grades' standard deviation figure compared to the standard deviation of science and mathematics grades indicated that differentiated instruction reached many more learners and a higher achievement level was attained.

en: IV ABSTRACT TIME SERIES ANALYSIS OF CURRENT IN PMMA The time evolution of the transient current passing through PMMA polymer thin films under 10 V, at 23Â° C (296 K) was sampled at intervals of ten and twenty seconds. The resultant time series for the current has been analyzed by delay time reconstruction of the phase space. In the analysis two different time scales have been observed; the first one as the first zero crossing of the correlation function, which is at 8380 seconds and the second one as the first marked minimum of the average mutual information at 40 seconds. The letter has been chosen as time delay in the calculation of the maximal Lyapunov exponent. The existence of widely different time scales has thus forced non-linear methods to be used. A positive maximal Lyapunov exponent has been observed thus implying the possibility of chaotic behavior. Collective effects such as pinned charge density effects or competitive damping and forcing mechanisms arising from the applied electric field are possible causes for this behavior.

en: In this thesis, electrical conduction, in thin films of chalcogenide glasses, was studied. As2Se3, As2Te3 and AS2S3 samples have been subjected to electric fields of the order of 10^0-10^3V/cm and their d.c. conductivities were measured at temperatures between 200-410K, 200-360K and 200-360K respectively. Generally, the conductivity shows an exponential relation with the temperature of type a=Cexp(-E/kT). An application of the results to the above relation indicates a dominance of extended state conduction for As2Se3 and AS2Te3 while hopping conduction is observed for AS2S3. A.c. conductivity o f As2Se3, AS2Te3 and AS2S3 samples were measured at temperatures 200-410K, 200-360K and 200-360K respectively in the frequency range between 5Hz and 5MHz. The results suggest that the conductivity consists of two components, one being independent of frequency and the other varying as w^s with frequency. The experimental results are in agreement with the Classical Barrier Hopping (CBH) conductivity model assuming different mechanisms for the d.c. and a.c. conductivities rather than the Extended Pair Approximation (EPA) model assuming the same mechanism for both d.c. and a.c. conductivities.

en: IV ABSTRACT FREQUENCY-RESOLVED PHOTOCONDUCTIVITY STUDIES IN AMORPHOUS CHALCOGENIDE FILMS Frequency-resolved photocurrent measurements (FRPC) were carried out on amorphous chalcogenide films such as AsSeSb AsSe and AsSeTe, by a method called frequency-resolved spectroscopy (FRS) as a function of temperature (between 230 K and 395 K), of excitation intensity (between 40 Watts/m2 and 600 Watts/m2) and in the frequency range of 1 0 Hz to 1. 1 x 1 04 Hz, yielding the lifetime distribution directly. The results indicate that the recombination is through distant pairs, since the lifetime does depend on the excitation intensity, through t = AGV ;as tÂ« q-Â°m at 295 K and T oc G~0'77 at 395 K, rather than by geminate (twin) pairs. It can also be concluded that there is a continuous distribution of states in the mobility gap implied by the value of the exponent 0.72 (in I ph Â«G0,72), which is between 0.5 and 1.0, the figures that according to Rose (1978), correspond respectively to monomolecular and bimolecular recombination. The temperature exponent n in the relationship I ph Â°= T" has turned out to be between 7 and 10 for a frequency of some coQ (=200 Hz); and 1 1 and 13 for 17Ã»)0 (=3322 Hz); the value of the exponent showing a diminishing behaviour as the generation rate (intensity of excitation) is elevated. Finally, the exponent s in the relationship I ph Â°= on" is found to depend on both temperature T and the generation rate G in a manner such that the photocurrent will be more sensitive (inversely) to the frequency of excitation as either one of the above variables or both are lowered.

en: IV ABSTRACT CYLINDRICALLY SYMMETRIC COSMIC STRINGY MEMBRANES AND THEIR TRANSMUTATIONS Cylindrically symmetric cosmic stringy membranes and their transmutations into one another are investigated with the help of a metric ansatz which as special cases includes a single cosmic string, a cylindrical stringy surface and a string decaying into cones at its endpoints. The new configurations studied include a cylinder decaying into conical surfaces at its endpoints and ending up as a sheet with radial strings. A string changing into a cylinder and a cylinder changing into a cylinder with larger radius are also investigated. These latter however are found to give rise to negative energy densities at the one stage of their evolution.

en: IV ABSTRACT Dirac's canonical quantization method is reviewed. Dirac brackets for a constrained relativistic system is calculated with and without a gauge condition. The violation of the Jacobi identity problem of the Dirac brackets is solved by practically working out the Jacobi identities with different choices of Second class constraints. Without fixing the gauge quantization is performed by constructing the Dirac brackets that satisfy Jacobi identity at the classical level. Using gauge invariant operators, the re sulting commutator algebras are investigated in connection with the Pusz-Woronowicz q-oscillator.

en: IV ABSTRACT THE INVARIANT FUNCTION APPROACH TO RECURSION RELATIONS FOR EXACTLY SOLUBLE QUANTUM POTENTIALS AND THE RELATIVISTIC HYDROGEN ATOM Potentials allowing exact solution of the SchrÃ¶dinger equation have attracted interest starting from the early years of quantum mechanics. Among the various methods of obtaining them, comparison of the SchrÃ¶dinger equation to a known, second order differential equation is the most straightforward one. Previous studies have already revealed that exactly soluble potentials fall into two groups: 1) potentials related to the confluent hypergeometric and 2) potentials related to the hypergeometric differential equations. After exact solutions are known it is natural to apply methods of perturbation theory for computing diagonal matrix elements. In this work recursion relations for expectation values are found using the invariant function approach. The general recursion relation obtained for Class I potentials is also applied to the relativistic Hydrogen atom problem. DOKÃœMANTASYON MEBMM

en: IV Abstract Accretion onto a compact object is the process that is thought to power un expectedly intense radiation of some astrophysical objects like Active Galactic Nuclei and X-Ray Binaries. A similar process is known to exist in Cataclysmic Variables and Young Stellar Objects. When the accreting matter has enough angular momentum it forms a disc around the compact object (a black hole, neutron star or white dwarf) and this disc is called an accretion disc. In this theses accretion discs around compact objects are studied both ana lytically and numericaly. Simplifying hydrodynamic equations in their full generality by the assumptions of the standart accretion disc theory both time-independent and time-dependent equations were solved analytically. Time-dependent solutions are sup ported by numerical results. In all solutions a viscosity prescription which is a little more generalized than the standart prescription is used. The solution of the time- dependent equations with the generalized viscosity belong to the same family with the earlier ones.

en: IV ABSTRACT Determination of the source of a particular marble sample is an ongoing subject of study among archaeometrists. In this study, categorization according to pore size distribution is suggested. The employed method for pore size analysis is Phase Transition Porosimetry (PTP). The principles on which PTP works are described. PTP requires a computer system for data taking and data processing. The electronic data-acquisition system and the control software are discussed extensively. After construction of a dilatometric Phase Transition Porosimeter, marble samples collected from field have been studied with this method and the results are given. The precision of PTP in low-porosity materials are discussed using the results.

en: IV ABSTRACT A DQ Her type Cataclysmic Variable X-ray binary system, TV Colubae, was observed for 22557s with the ROSAT PSPC in the range 0. 1-2.4 keV. As a result of spectral analyses of the X-ray data of TV Col, it is seen that the best model to the 0.1-2.4 keV spectrum is a power law with photon index T = -1.1100 Â± 0.0587 through a column density of NH (102Icm ~2) = 0.179 Â± 0.026. Apart from the distinctive features exhibited by the source activity, the common process responsible for the soft X-ray emission regardless of the source state seems to be magnetic in origin. Although the total exposure time of TV Col observed by the ROSAT PSPC was 22557s which is expected to cover at least 1 1 complete spin periods of the white dwarf, the power spectrum obtained over the whole integrated data was not able to confirm the 32 minute (1920s) rotational period of the compact star due to the Earth blockage and fundamental cycle around 2100s imposed on the data by the satellite orbit.

en: IV ABSTRACT A fiber optic experimental technique was developed for the determination of optical constants and thermal characterization of titanium dioxide and zirconium dioxide optical coatings. Such coatings were deposited directly onto the end face of mullimodc and single mode optical fibers by an electron beam evaporation technique, under a vacuum chamber. Refractive index (n), extinction coefficient (k), thermal optical coefficient (dn/dT), and thickness (d) of the coatings were in situ determined from their reflection spectra. A fiber optic thin film temperature sensor based on dn/dT of TÄ°O2 and ZrC>2 was constructed using n, k, d and dn/dT values.

en: IV Abstract We investigate two problems in this work. In the first, the basic motivation is to incorporate spontaneous symmetry breaking and gravitation into the context of a scalar-tensor theory. Non-zero value of the minimum of the potential provides the present-day value of the gravitational constant. We present sample solutions for differ ent potentials, however, our main emphasis is on the globally conformal invariant case. The solutions are approximate in the sense that they are characterized by the scale of the vacuum expectation value of the scalar field. In the Einstein frame, an equation of state is derived. According to this equation of state, cosmology is dominated by the scalar field both in the early and the present universe and the scalar field supplies the critical density of the universe today. The mass of the scalar field, depending on its vacuum expectation value, is determined by the present-day values of the Planck mass and the Hubble constant. For Electroweak Theory Higgs field this leads to a long-range coupling stronger than gravity, between the scalar field and matter. The second problem contains systematic means for finding inhomogeneous solutions. In the second problem, we apply the long-wavelength approximation to the low-energy effec tive string action in the context of the Hamilton-Jacobi theory. The Hamilton-Jacobi equation for the effective string action is explicitly invariant under scale factor duality. We present the leading-order, general solution of the Hamilton-Jacobi equation. The Hamilton-Jacobi approach yields a solution consistent with the Lagrange formalism. The momentum constraints take an elegant, simple form. Furthermore, this general solution reduces to the quasi-isotropic one, if the evolution of the gravitational radia tion is neglected. The duality transformation for the general solution is written as a coordinate transformation in an abstract space of fields.

en: In this thesis, unitary matrix representation of quantum group SUq(2) is studied in terms of stereographic coordinates z, z * and its central unitary phase u. It is observed that this parametrization of SUq(2) can be regarded as a q _1 -oscillator representation of SUq(2) where q~x > 1. The fractional linear transformation of z and z* which gives the action of SUq(2) on the quantum sphere SUq(2)/U(l) is studied. Then we extend this action to SUq(2) and derive the transformation law of u. In the final part of this work, transformation laws for dz and operator Ã¢ are also studied.

en: III ABSTRACT In order to investigate the possibility of the construction of a sample PET coinci dence unit in our HEP laboratory, a setup with two face to face PMTs and two 2x8 CsI(Tl) scintillator matrices has been constructed. In this setup, 1-D projections of a pointlike 22Na positron source at different angles have been measured. Using these projections a 2-D image has been formed. Monte Carlo studies of this setup have been implemented using the detector simulation tool in CERN program library, GEANT. Again with GEANT a sample human body is created to study the effects of proton therapy. Utilization of the simulation as a pretherapy tool is also investigated.

Biz hesaplarÄ±mÄ±zda birinci ve ikinci derece pertÃ¼rbasyon ve varyasyon yÃ¶ntemleri ile har- monik salÄ±nÄ±cÄ± Ã¶zdurumlarÄ±nÄ± baz alarak kartezyen ve polar koordinatlarÄ±n ikisini de kullanarak frekans optimizasyonu yapmadan beklenen deÄŸerleri ve yaklaÅŸÄ±klÄ±k Ã¶lÃ§Ã¼lerini hesap ettik. ÃœÃ§Ã¼ncÃ¼ integralin beklenen deÄŸerini de bu operatÃ¶rlerdeki konum ve mo mentuma baÄŸlÄ± Ã§arpÄ±mlarÄ±n simetriÄŸini kullanarak hermitsel yaptÄ±ktan sonra bulduk ve yaklaÅŸÄ±klÄ±ÄŸÄ±nÄ± inceledik.
en: IV ABSRACT The Toda lattice is an exactly integrable cyclic system with three degrees of free dom and next neighbor interaction. None of its truncations are integrable. The Henon- Heiles system is the third order truncation of all cyclic systems with three degrees of freedom and next neighbor interaction. It only possesses two integrals and is usually given as an example of Hamiltonian chaos. Approximate third integrals have been con structed for this system classically. The fourth order truncations of the Toda lattice have been studied as model systems with approximate constants of motion quantum mechanically, using different approximate techniques. Constructing approximate integrals of the Henon-Heiles system by using truncations of the Toda lattice integrals is an attractive possibility. Classically, a combination of the Hamiltonian and the third integral gives an approximate integral that is correct up to the fifth order. A generalization of the above result for the quantum mechanical case involves the following difficulties: the poor convergence properties of the perturbative treatment of the anharmonic oscillator problem, difficulties in constructing appropriate bound state wave functions for the weakly bound Henon-Heiles system and difficulties in constructing a quantum mechanical generalization for the terms that mix p and q in the third integral. Berry has calculated the expectation values and approximate time dependent quan tities for the z component of the angular momentum operator and its square for the fourth order truncation of the Toda Hamiltonian. This combination of operators occurs in the averaged form of the classical approximate integrals. The calculation is based on a wave packet in which he used both oscillator and Morse wavefunctions and a first order perturbation expansion. We have used the wave packets that are based on both the first order and second order perturbation of harmonic oscillator problem and a vari ational calculation based on a linear combination of wave functions in cartesian and polar coordinates without frequency optimization. The expectation value and approxi mation quality of the classical third integral has been calculated using its symmetrized version.

en: IV ABSTRACT An invariant measure on SUq(2), the invariant distance on SUq(2) and on the quantum sphere S% are constructed. By contraction we define an invariant measure, an integral on Eq(2) and an invariant distance on the quantum plane E"1. It is shown that the matrix elements of the unitary irreducible representations of Eq(2) can be obtained from those of SUq{2) by contraction. Using symmetries of the invariant integral and the matrix elements of unitary irreducible representations we construct a Planscherel measure on Eq{2). Generalized functions on Eq(2), SUq{2) and its homogeneous spaces are defined. As examples of physical applications we give the explicit form of ther Green function and the Kernel on the quantum sphere Sq. On the example of quantum sphere we generalize the path integral formalism. The Green's function for massless scalar fields on the q-Einstein space Sq x R and the q-Minkowski space E* x R are constructed. The Green's function for the quantum oscillator is also denned.

en: After presenting some mathematical and physical arguments for deformed algebras, various q oscillators and their invariance groups are given. Some physical models from which the deformation parameter q emerges are studied. These are non-canonical quantization of constrained systems and q statistics. Finally some implications of these new approaches are investigated.

en: AE Aquarii, a DQ Her type Cataclysmic Variable X-ray binary system, is observed with ROSAT, PSPC in the energy range 0. 1-2.4 keV with a total of 5.74 hr period. As a result of spectral and timing analyses of the ROSAT X-ray data of AE Aquarii, it is found that both a very low mass accretion rate of 8.59 x 10~13 M yr-1 estimated from the X-ray luminosity and a QPO like structure observed in the X-ray average power spectrum support the magnetic propeller scenario in which the gas blobs of the inhomogeneous accretion stream from the secondary star to the white dwarf are radiated thermally near the white dwarf surface because of the shock heating of the gas blobs at supersonic speeds in the high accretion state of AE Aquarii. On the other hand, the accreted gas particles are radiated magnetically in ~ 107 Gauss of magnetosphere far away from the white dwarf surface during the low accretion states.

The relations between the Lax formalism and bi -Hamiltonian structures are analysed and illustrated with well known examples such as the KdV system. Various methods resulting from this analysis are then applied to multicomponent KdV equations.

en: Ill Abstract This thesis study will in general be handling physics analysis concerned with the ATLAS detector at the LHC at CERN. However, reader will find a historical introduc tion about CERN. We will be mentioning the purpose of establishing such a labrotary, the developments, achievements, goals and future plans in chronological order. An efficient description of the experiment will be introduced in terms of the physics goals, detector's construction, working principle, its subsystems and data flow charac teristics. Besides the structure of the detector, we will be mentioning the structure of the LHC. The main part of this work will be the physics and trigger analysis using the fast simulation program ATLFAST, to which we had officially introduced the routine for the muon trigger efficiencies during our studies at CERN. The H - > ZZ* - > 4/i signal, and its backgrounds will be analyzed with and without trigger requirements.

en: ABSTRACT Representations of the braided algebra of BMq(2) are found. It is shown that the braided algebra can be realized by a pair of q, q~l oscillators. It is found that there are only two Hopf algebra structures for the positive determinant and no Hopf algebra structure for the zero and negative determinants. It is also shown that BMq{2) and BMq-\ (2) share the same Hopf algebra structure. The right-left covariance symmetry of BMq(2) is shown to be a q -Â» Ã§-1 symmetry. A linear transformation between the generators of BMq(2) and BMq-i (2) is constructed. The results obtained are applied to the c-Minkowski space. In this context, two different Hopf algebra structures are built for the q-Minkowski space, a new g-Minkowski space with the deformation parameter g-1 is defined, and a linear transformation between the two space coordinates is presented. A generalized oscillator is proposed and the solutions for the generalized braided Hopf algebra structure of this generalized oscillator are presented. Finally, the solutions for some special cases (the linear g-oscillator, the Fibonacci oscillator, the Biedenharn-Macfarlane oscillator and the Heisenberg algebra) of the generalized oscillator are given.

en: IV Abstract The object of this thesis is the non-numerical calculation of Lyapunov exponents in continuous time dynamical systems. This work has been motivated by the requirements of separating computational error in the calculation of zero Lyapunov exponents. As a byproduct it has yielded two scenarios for the characterization of patterns of chaotic behavior in three dimensional systems. These two scenarios cover a large variety of three dimensional non-linear chaotic systems including the well known Lorenz and RÃ¶ssler systems. In addition, the presence of a pair of complex conjugate eigenvalues indicates the presence of a zero Lyapunov exponent implying an attractor, which is necessary for the existence of an attractor.

Sicim teorisinde bir asimptotik dÃ¼zlÃ¼k tanÄ±mÄ± verilmiÅŸ ve gelecek Ä±ÅŸÄ±ksal sonsuzda Bondi kÃ¼tlesi, elektromanyetik yÃ¼k ve dilaton yÃ¼kÃ¼ ifadeleri bulunmuÅŸtur.
en: IV Abstract A generalization of the Robinson-Trautman family is obtained for low-energy string theory as well as for certain other dilatonic theories in four space-time dimensions. The space-times in this new family called the stringy Robinson-Trautman family ad mit both diverging and nondiverging null congruences. It is found that the generalized Robinson-Trautman solutions are frame independent in string theory, and that the Lorentz Chern-Simons three-form of the stringy Robinson-Trautman space-times are always closed. The field equations are studied, and the generalizations of the vacuum Robinson-Trautman equation are obtained. It is shown that the dilatonic black holes, the stringy C-metric, pp waves and certain other solutions which are known to cor respond to exact conformal field theories belong to the Robinson-Trautman family as particular members. New radiating, asymptotically flat, Petrov type D solutions are obtained and studied. It is proven that one of these solutions settles down smoothly to a positive mass dilatonic black hole in late positive retarded times, and that an other settles down smoothly to a negative mass dilatonic black hole at late negative retarded times. In order to understand the existence and the behaviour of the stringy Robinson-Trautman solutions, some linear perturbations are examined, and it is found that there are diverging modes of these perturbations. Lyapunov's functional approach is employed for determining the behaviour of solutions, and space-times of constant magnetic charge are found to be asymptotically stable in the Lyapunov's sense. A definition of the asymptotic flatness in string theory is given and the Bondi mass, the electromagnetic charge, and the dilatonic charge at future null infinity are obtained.

en: IV ABSTRACT In this thesis, a Fizeau type pressure sensor is described. The sensor consists of 500 |j.m cavity length with two reflecting mirrors. A single-mode optical fiber designed at a wavelength of 780 nm which was connected to a laser diode of 788 nm wavelength to carry incident laser light onto the cavity and acts as addressing fiber to collect the reflected laser light from the same cavity. The cleaved end-face of the addressing fiber was made to act as proximal mirror of 4 % reflectivity for the Fizeau cavity. The distal mirror was formed from a diaphragm of about 5 to 10 jam thick polished aluminium metal. The cleaved-end-face of the addressing fiber was inserted into a zirconia ferrule of 1.8 mm outside diameter. The fiber end and the diaphragm were held together via a stainless steal cylinder. The transduction mechanism of the pressure sensor was based on two-beam interference. The pressure measurement values are between 0 to about 300 torr.

en: IV ABSTRACT In this study, a gain scheduled controller for a PWR nuclear power plant has been developed to control the system power level between 10-120 per cent of nominal power. The dynamic system was modeled as a multivariable, parameter varying system. The main design criteria were system safety, reduction of the number of repetitive calculations, an improvement in reactor temperature response, and robustness. The controller was implemented on an IBM compatible PC using MATLAB and its simulation software package SIMULINK. During the design stage, several approaches were applied to obtain an easily implement able, thoroughly stable, and sufficiently robust controller. The most drastic difficulty was encountered in the implementation. It seemed however not possible to design a simple gain scheduled controller that satisfies our design criteria for the model considered. Throughout simulations, the performance of the gain scheduled controller was compared to the performances of a linear quadratic regulator and a set-theoretic controller designed at full power. Also, it was observed that the effect of power variation on the performance and stability was insignificant; therefore, the designed controller is sufficiently robust for the aforementioned power range.

en: IV Abstract In this thesis, an extensive study of the production of light inside the fiber and the detection of this light together with its conversion into electrical pulses by the photo- multiplier tubes have been presented. Basic constituents of a typical scintillating fiber detector and their operation principles have been described. Fundamental mechanisms governing the light propagation through the fiber have been discussed by elaborating the fiber geometry. Radiation sources like Co60, Cs137, Sr90 emitting energetic photons and electrons have been used for measurements. Some parameters characterizing the performance and the quality of scintillating fibers to construct fast and efficient detec tor were investigated and the results were presented. Particularly, the variation of light intensity as a function of distance with double component behavior was observed and the sensitivity of a photomultiplier to photoelectrons was measured. By subtracting average noise levels from raw data and applying some techniques like cluster analysis, common bias level subtraction etc... we were able to obtain position of the source located over the fiber bundle with 2.4mm resolution.

en: IV Abstract The use of deformed derivatives in quantum mechanics, and in quantum field theory is studied. The motivation is that the deformed derivative approach should remove the divergences present in the loop diagrams of the interacting fields. In one dimension it is shown that there is a connection between q-oscillators, special relativity and difference operators. In three dimensions it is shown that the deformed derivative approach automatically brings in the spin phenomena, and that the deformation makes the Coulomb potential regular everywhere. en: IV Abstract We have studied several methods to achieve the best spatial resolution and the highest track reconstruction efficiency using the limited streamer tube planes with external pickup strips orthogonal to the signal wires and the analog readout of the CHORUS Muon Spectrometer. The analysis has been performed with real data of 100 GeV beam muons and cosmic muons at CERN Labrotary in Geneva. Using a combined algorithm of common bias level subtraction and an empirical function to determine the center of the induced charge distribution on the 18 mm wide strips, we have obtained a spatial resolution of about 3 mm.

en: -*' Ä°NGÄ°LÄ°ZCE ABSTRAKT (en fazla 250 sÃ¶zcÃ¼k ) LÄ± this work, methods for the determination of Lyapunov exponents are studied. Lyapunov exponents measure the expanded rate of divergence of nearby trajectories and thus serve as a nonlocal criterion for chaotic behavior. For continuous-time dynamical systems characterized by differential equations, the method proposed by Wolf et al. which relies on the direct variation of the equations of motion, the method proposed by Wiesel which also perform reorthogonalization in continuous-time and the eigenvalue method proposed by Eckmann and Ruelle are used. Each of these methods are implemented for automated use, starting from the given dynamical system, by judicious combination of symbolic programming and numerical analysis. The methods are applied to Lorenz, RÃ¶ssler and Van der Pol systems. These are standard systems exhibiting chaotic behavior, furthermore the Van der Pol system possesses two characteristic time scales, one of which can be eliminated by averaging. Results from different methods agree with each other and with values reported elsewhere. The characterization of an attractor from a measured time signal and calculation of the largest Lyapunov exponent is also studied by using one dimensional data obtained from numerical integration of these systems as input. Results agree with those found by continuous-time methods.

en: IV ABSTRACT In this thesis, a new method to determine optical constants (n,k), thickness, absorption coefficient (a), optical band gap (Eg) and dielectric constants (ft.ft) of chalcogenide thin films of As.40Se.40Te.20 andAs2Se3 is introduced. As.40Se.40Te.20 and As2Se3 are coated onto the cleaved end face of multimode optical fibres and the transmittance spectrum is obtained. The other investigation is on the change in optical constants and optical band gap of As.40Se.40Te.20 upon annealing. It is shown that the results are in agreement with the ones in the literature.

en: IV ABSTRACT In this thesis, the characteristics of a Si sample with dimensions of 10mm x 4mm are investigated The characteristics involve the conductivity type, resistance, resistivity, conductivity, mobility, and carrier concentration. The metal- semiconductor contacts (Al- pSi), both ohmic and rectifying, are analyzed and the barrier height of the Schottky diode is calculated. Haynes Shockley Experiment is tried for the determination of the excess minority carriers. Although the characteristics of the Si sample are achieved successfully, The Haynes Shockley Experiment is unsuccessful. The reasons for the failure of this experiment and the methods to overcome the problems will be discussed in this thesis.

tr: Ã–zet Uzay-zaman dualitesi veya T-dualitesi diye bilmen sicim teorisinin en temel simetri lerinden biri incelenmiÅŸtir. en: 11 Abstract One of tlie fundamental symmetries of string theory, known as spacetime duality or T-duality, is studied. This symmetry can be established if the target space has an isometry. In the Lagrangian approach the spacetime duality can be interpreted as gauging the isometry. In the Hamiltonian approach, the duality corresponds to a simple canonical transformation. Duality transformations are derived and the global aspects of the problem are considered. It is shown that spacetime duality is a map between two manifolds that have completely different topological and geometrical structures. If the isometry is compact, these two manifolds correspond to the same conformal field theory and are equivalent from the string theory point of view. We determine the effect of the duality transformations on the basic geometrical and physical quantities and identify invariants. Among these the description of the equations that follow from the isometry and the covariantization of the condition for the preservation of supersymmetry can be claimed to be original.

en: ABSTRACT The transmission spectrum of chalcogenide thin films had been measured and the optical constants were determined. The obtained data were used to determine the surface topology and optical band gap of thin films. (As2Se3). 8sSb. 15 and As. 4oSe 4oTe. 20 thin films produced by thermal evaporation method were used. The wavelength range covers a spectrum of 300 - 1100 nm. The optical constants involve the index of refraction, the absorption coefficient and the extinction coefficient. To obtain thickness as a function of position, a two dimensional positioner was constructed. Since the area of the focused light was 1 mm^ the resolution was limited to 1 mm^.

en: IV ABSTRACT Determination of the energetic distribution of localized states due to random network and structural defects within the mobility gap of amorphous semi conductors is of great importance for understanding the transport properties of these materials. Since there is no structural order, the band states can be only determined experimentally. In this thesis, the density of states (DOS) distribution in the energy gap of Hydrogenated n-type amorphous silicon is determined. For this purpose a The Phase shift analysis of modulated photocurrent (PSAMP) method is studied. The validity of the PSAMP theorem for the doped a-H:Si is discussed. The theorem is verified for this type of semiconductors and the distribution of the states is determined for a range of 400 meV.

Applying voltages around Â±40 volts and at different temperatures dc conductivity of the samples has been measured. This branch of conductivity shows generally an exponential relation with temperature of the form <7= C exp (-E/kT). One can see that for T above room temperature, extended state conductivity predominates. In the second part, ac conductivity has been measured at various frequencies and different temperatures. Results showed mat the two conductivities (ac and dc) originate differently, confirming the CBH model expecting different mechanisms. The exponent s (in a oc of) is calculated to be ~ 0.9 for T > 300 K down to room temperature; and ~ 1 for T < 300 K. As for the exponent n (in o oc T"), it is found to be ~ 1.6. v. ^0

en: IV ABSTRACT The Standard Model introduces the masses of the gauge bosons and fermions through the electroweak symmetry-breaking mechanism, or Higgs mechanism. The experimental proof for Higgs mechanism requires the finding of the Higgs boson. The mass of the Higgs boson is not predicted in the theory; therefore, the whole Higgs mass spectrum, which reaches up to 1 TeV/c2, must be searched. So far, the experiments at LEP (electron-positron collider at CERN) were able to exclude the region up to 60 GeV/c2 (LEP200 will reach 80GeV/c2). The search over the complete spectrum will be possible with LHC (Large Hadron Collider). The simulations done for the proposed ATLAS detector for LHC has shown that Higgs signal can be seen in the following channels: H -> 77 (80 < mH < 150 GeV/c2); H -Â» ZZ* -> llll (130 ZZ -* llll (180 < mH < 800 GeV/c2)- H -+ ZZ -> llvv (500 < mH < 800 GeV/c2). This study, which has been done within ATLAS Collaboration, has simulated the semi-leptonic decay channels (H - > WW - > Ivjj, H - > ZZ - > lljj) of a 1 TeV/c2 Higgs and reached the conclusion that the signal can be extracted from the backgrounds with an optimized jet algorithm, the application of kinematic cuts on the decay products and jet tagging. en: IV ABSTRACT In this thesis, light-induced metastable changes in hydrogenated amorphous silicon thin films are investigated. The Staebler-Wronski effect is observed and studied. On the basis of the experimental data concerning the changes in dark conductivity, photoconductivity, and temperature dependence of dark conductivity of the films upon prolonged light-soaking, it is found that among the two basic models recently proposed to account for the mechanism of the light-induced metastable defect formation, the charge-trapping defect model seems to be much more adequate than the weak-bond breaking model. A future work is also formulated and suggested in the conclusion part. ÃETÄ°M Wmni MOM MÂ£jjftt,.,

en: In this work, we have investigated the spectral and temporal properties of the brightest X-ray source (GX5-1) in the bulge of our Galaxy, using the data obtained from the LAC instrument onboard the Ginga satellite. We have found that neither single-component spectral model (blackbody, thermal bremsstrahlung or power law) is adequate to fit the X-ray spectrum of GX5-1. The best fit is reached by using a. two-component model including a power law with exponential cut-off (PLEC) and a blackbody (BB). We have found positive evidence for the presence of a scattering cloud surrounding the neutron star, with a Thomson optical depth of '" 5. The PLEC component is attributed to Comptonized emission in the scattering cloud while the BB component originates from an emission region in the inner accretion disk. In contrast to some previous observations the source has been found to show only a, normal branch (NB) in its colour-colour diagram, but no horizontal branch (HB). We have found that the source shows no periodic intensity variations but a qua.siperiodic behaviour, interpreted by some models in terms of the fluctuations in the optical depth of the Comptonized medium.

AyrÄ±ca, hareketli dalga Ã§Ã¶zÃ¼mlerinin kararsÄ±z bÃ¶lgede dallandÄ±ktan sonra hareketli dalga karakterlerini koruduklarÄ± gÃ¶rÃ¼lmÃ¼ÅŸ ve ka rarsÄ±zlÄ±ÄŸÄ±n hareketli dalga Ã§Ã¶zÃ¼mlerine karÅŸÄ±lÄ±k gelen simetri grubu altÄ±nda invaryant kaldÄ±ÄŸÄ± sonucuna varÄ±lmÄ±ÅŸtÄ±r. AraÅŸtÄ±rma sonucu elde edilen bulgular yorumlanmÄ±ÅŸ ve ileride yapÄ±labilecek Ã§alÄ±ÅŸmalara da ayrÄ±ca deÄŸinilmiÅŸtir.
en: IV ABSTRACT In this work, we have investigated the instability in some travelling wave (TW) solutions of a pair of coupled Nonlinear SchrÃ¶dinger Equations (cNLSE) arising from laser beam propagation in lossless nonlinear optical media. The TW case is of par ticular interest because it represents solitonic wave propagation, one of the most important phenomena observed in experiments. Using the Lie Groups of Symmetries method and a special form of a solution, the cNLSE's are reduced to four coupled first-order nonlinear Ordinary Differential Equations (ODE). The resulting ODE are in Hamiltonian form and represent the TW character of the original equations. In order to understand the instabilities in the resulting equations, we have applied reli able numerical methods from Dynamical Systems Theory such as the power spectrum analysis and the Lyapunov Characteristic Exponent (LCE) calculation. As a result, we find the region of instability, and observe that this behavior is directly related to the input intensity, i.e., input power of the laser beam, and local behavior of the self-focusing nonlinear medium. The homoclinic instability observed here, has im portant theoretical implications. In addition, it is strongly emphasized that the TW solutions found here bifurcate to other TW solutions, indicating a bifurcation that preserves symmetries of the system. We have concluded this work by summarizing our findings and indicating possibilities for future extensions.

tr: Kuantum gruplarÄ±na dayalÄ± ayar alan teorisi modelleri tartÄ±ÅŸÄ±ldÄ±ldÄ±. SUq(2) kuantum grubunun Lie cebri analogunun elemanÄ± olan jeneratÃ¶rler bulundu. en: Possible formulations of gauge field models where the gauge group is a quantum group are discussed. The exponential map from the generators of the Lie algebra analog of the quantum group SUq(2) to the quantum group SUq(2) itself is presented. The q-deformed Yang-Mills theory is introduced via the definition of the q-trace and the q-deformed Yang- Mills lagrangian which is invariant under the quantum group gauge transformations. The gauge field takes values in the quantum universal enveloping algebra of SUq(2). As a result of this construction a Weinberg type mixing angle which depends on the quantum group deformation parameter q is obtained. The representations of the n-braid group where generators are given essentially by 2x2 matrices whose elements belong to a noncommutative algebra are presented. The Burau representation arises as a special (commuting) case of this algebra. A closely related algebra to the braid algebra is introduced and it is shown that the generalized oscillator system given by this algebra generates a hydrogen-like spectrum. ^ESZSES

Bu Ã§Ã¶zÃ¼mlere iliÅŸkin Newman-Penrose deÄŸiÅŸkenleri hesaplanmaktadÄ±r. SonuÃ§lar genel gÃ¶recelikteki Reissner-NordstrÃ¶m kara deliklerinin Ã¶zellikleriyle karÅŸÄ±laÅŸtÄ±rÄ±lmaktadÄ±r. Sicim teorisinin kara deliklerin tekillik yapÄ±larÄ±nÄ±, ufuklarÄ±nÄ± ve termodinamik Ã¶zelliklerim deÄŸiÅŸtirdiÄŸi fakat cebirsel Ã¶zelliklerini koruduÄŸu gÃ¶rÃ¼lmektedir. Son olarak daha genel bir Ã§Ã¶zÃ¼mler sÄ±nÄ±fÄ± olan sicim Robinson-Trautman ailesi oluÅŸturulmaktadÄ±r. Bu yeni ailenin Ã¶zel bir hal olarak sicim kara deliklerini iÃ§erdiÄŸi gÃ¶sterilmektedir.
en: IV ABSTRACT Charged black hole solutions of the string theory are studied in four space-time dimension within the framework of an effective string action. Since electrically charged or the dyonic solutions can be obtained by generalized duality rotations, only the magnetically charged black holes are considered. The trajectories of neutral test particles on a stringy black hole background are determined. The Hawking temperature and the entropy of a stringy black hole are discussed. The Newman-Penrose variables for these solutions are computed. The results are compared with the properties of the Reissner-NordstrÃ¶m black holes of general relativity. It is found that string theory modifies the singularity structure, horizons and the thermal properties of the black holes in an interesting manner but preserves the algebraic properties of these space-times. A more general class of solutions to the string field equations, the stringy Robinson-Trautman family is then constructed. It is shown that this new family contains, as a special case, the stringy black hole solutions.

en: SCALAR FIELDS IN NONABELIAN KALUZA-KLEIN THEORIES The components of the Riemann curvature tensor are calculated for a general pseudo-Riemannian space which is the product of usual space- time and 3n internal space that is chosen to be a group manifold. Explicit calculations are presented for G=SU(2)XU( 1 ). It is shown that, if Einstein- Hilbert action is used the scalar fields so obtained are massive, whereas if an Euler form action is used, the scalar fields are massless Moreover, the scalar fields so obtained, exhibit a nonlinear sigma-model structure

en: iv ABSTJRACT MECHANICAL PROPERTIES OF THE BEAD WIRE Force and strain analysis of the bead bundle suggest that major effects on the mechanical properties of steel bead wires within bead bundles were due to bending moments caused by local pressure variations at bead-rim interface, creating a beam bending problem. Laboratory work consisted of tensile and fatigue tests performed on steel bead wires of bead bundles belonging to tires that have run for varying distances. The primary goal was to determine the relation between the distance the tire travels and the change in mechanical properties of the bead bundle. Fatigue tests have been performed on the Rotating Beam Fatigue Tester which simulated the actual deformation conditions within a bead bundle seated on a rim. Experimental findings have then been verified with fractographic investigation of steel bead wire characteristics on the optical and Scanning Electron Microscopes of steel bead wires. The research provided successfull evidence to reach to the conclusion that as the distance a tire travels increases the mechanical properties of its beads and hence the steel bead wires become more viable to failure due to softening of the material and loss of durability.

en: IV THE VERTEX OPERATOR ALGEBRA IN STRING THEORY We present the explicit commutator algebra of integrated vertex operators for all states of the bosonic string in 26 dimensions. When the momenta belong to the unique even self-dual lattice II25,1, this is the Monster Lie algebra MÂ» of Borcherds, Conway, Queen and Sloane, containing all other rank 26 Lorentzian algebras. We note that in a process 1+2- Â»3 described by string theory, the on-shell momenta qi, qz and q3 are necessarily restricted to an even lattice L in R25-1 as a result of the fact that qi2=2n (l>neZ), hence the Lorentzian algebras such as Moo may be expected to be of direct relevance to string theory. We formulate and verify up to the fourth mass-level (q32=-6) the conjecture that the on shell amplitude A(l+2- >3) and the structure constant fi23 of MÂ» are identical. We briefly compare the implication that spacetime may have an underlying discrete structure corresponding to II25,1 with similar recent suggestions by Klebanov and Susskind, Polchinski and others.

en: A.c. and d.c. conductivity measurements have been per formed on amorphous silicon films produced by electron gun evaporation. The a.c. measurements have been performed at frequencies between 100 Hz and 2 MHz, and at temperatures between 150K and 400K. The d.c. behavior of the samples obey the T law between 771 and 250K. The a.c. conductivity of the films are well represented by the form Aw, where A and s are determined to be temperature dependent parameters. The data are discussed in terms of classical models based on pair approximation and a unified theory, the extended pair approxima tion, EPA. Although the a.c. behavior can be approximately explained by the Correlated Barrier Hopping model below 200K, the temperature and the frequency dependence are stronger than any classical model predicts. The a.c. data show a perfect agreement with the quasi-universal law predicted by the EPA calculations. However, quantitative calculations with the EPA results give unreasonable values for both the decay parameter a, and the rate parameter R. One of the major problems of the method of Phase shift analysis of modulated photocurrent, PSAMP, for studying thedensity of states in the energy gap of amorphous semiconductors has been the determination of the energy scale corresponding to this DOS profile. A new way of dealing with this problem is presented. A computer analysis is used to confirm the validity of this method and to demonstrate how it can be used. A simulation that is used to determine the sensitivity of the PSAMP method to the differences in the fine scale structures in the DOS distributions is presented. Four DOS distributions are considered and the expected data are obtained. The results show that the PSAMP method is very sensitive to such fine features in the DOS distributions. A comparison is also made with the sensitivity of other techniques commonly used in the determination of the DOS profiles.

en: ABSTRACT In this study the design and construction of a molecular nitrogen laser intended as a pump source for a dye laser system is presented. This laser emits radiation at a wavelength of 337.1 nanometers and uses Blumlein switching to achieve fast (~ a few nanosecond width) and high peaK power (~ a few hundred Kilowatts) pulses. It operates using atmospheric pressure nitrogen with a cavity length of ten centimeters. The incorporation of this laser into a wavelength tunable, pumped dye laser system is outlined. Methods for studying fast optical pulses are given. IV

en: V ABSTRACT A simple vacuum evaporation system has been designed and constructed in order to sublimate nickel-phthalocyanine on glass substrates. Techniques and theory required for establishing a simple vacuum evaporation system have been studied. Pumping facilities and connecting pipeworK has been specified. The skills and practice required for operating a vacuum system have been overviewed. ' A simple vacuum evaporation chamber has been designed, constructed, and operated. Pressures which fall in the high vacuum range have been attained in the vacuum chamber. In order to test the evaporation system, pure indium has been boiled under high vacuum and its film has been formed on a glass substrate. It has not been possible to obtain perceptable. evaporation of.iodine- or bromine- doped nicKel-phthalocyanine samples and to form films on glass substrates. Organic electrical conductors have been classified and studied. Energy band structures and charge transport mechanisms of organic charge transfer salts, halogen-doped organic polymers, and halogen-doped organic molecular crystals have been qualitatively investigated.

en: IV DETERMINATION' OF VOLATILIZATION RATES OF ORGANIC POLLUTANTS - CORRELATION OF RATE COEFFICENTS WITH PHYSICO-CHEMICAL PROPERTIES ABSTRACT This study, in principle, is concerned with the experimental determination of liquid phase mass transfer coefficients of some priority pollutants and the establish ment of a mul tivariable linear equation which correlates the measured rate coefficients with the computer-selected physico-chemical properties of the pollutant in question. The first part of the dissertation involves (i) a close literature review on mass transfer modes, and their appli cation to organic pollutants in solution, (ii) an experi mental study on the measurement of volatilization rates of eight high volatility and two low volatility synthetic organic chemicals which are commonly accepted as "pollu- vi ? tants threatening public health ". The experimental tech nique used is based on the assumption that the ratio of the volatilization rate constant of an organic chemical to the reaeration rate constant of oxygen is constant, provided that the rates are measured simultaneously in the samesolution. At the end of the first part, diffusion coeffi cients are calculated, and the value of the proportionality exponent in the correlation equation between volatilization- aeration rate ratios and molecular diffusivity ratios is estimated, and compared with values found in literature. The second part of the dissertation involves (i) the introduction of."Multiple Regression" technique as a linear model to correlate the measured volatil ization/reaeration rate ratios with the physico-chemical or molecular proper ties of the polluting chemical, (ii) introduction of a regression equation which involves the volatilization/ aeration rate coefficients as the dependent variable and Henry's constant, octanol -water partition coefficient, surface tension, total surface area and molecular diffu sion coefficient as the independent variables. A discussion is brought at the end, on the accuracy and applicability of the imposed equation in the field of environmental sciences.
